label: Software
definition: The class Software represents a series of computer instructions that tell the computer how to operate and execute specific tasks.

label: Physical Resource
definition: A material thing

label: Information Object
definition: Additional information to a process, like work schedule production plans, etc.

label: Goal
definition: The class Goal represents the desired outcome of a Function

label: ICC
definition: International Chamber of Commerce, the largest, most representative business organization in the world

label: Temporal Reference System
definition:
A temporal reference system, such as a temporal coordinate system (with an origin, direction, and scale), a calendar-clock combination, or a (possibly hierarchical) ordinal system. 

This is a stub class, representing the set of all temporal reference systems.

label: Temporal Reference System
definition:
Un sistema de referencia temporal, tal como un sistema de coordenadas temporales (con un origen, una dirección y una escala), una combinación calendario-reloj, o un sistema ordinal (posiblemente jerárquico).
        Esta clase comodín representa el conjunto de todos los sistemas de referencia temporal.

label: sistema de referencia temporal
definition:
A temporal reference system, such as a temporal coordinate system (with an origin, direction, and scale), a calendar-clock combination, or a (possibly hierarchical) ordinal system. 

This is a stub class, representing the set of all temporal reference systems.

label: sistema de referencia temporal
definition:
Un sistema de referencia temporal, tal como un sistema de coordenadas temporales (con un origen, una dirección y una escala), una combinación calendario-reloj, o un sistema ordinal (posiblemente jerárquico).
        Esta clase comodín representa el conjunto de todos los sistemas de referencia temporal.

label: Temporal Duration
definition: Time extent; duration of a time interval separate from its particular start position

label: Temporal Position
definition: A position on a time-line

label: Temporal Unit
definition: A standard duration, which provides a scale factor for a time extent, or the granularity or precision for a time position.

label: Time Position
definition: A temporal position described using either a (nominal) value from an ordinal reference system, or a (numeric) value in a temporal coordinate system.

label: Time Zone
definition:
A Time Zone specifies the amount by which the local time is offset from UTC. 
  A time zone is usually denoted geographically (e.g. Australian Eastern Daylight Time), with a constant value in a given region. 
The region where it applies and the offset from UTC are specified by a locally recognised governing authority.

label: day of week
definition: The day of week, whose value is a member of the class time:DayOfWeek

label: in time zone
definition: The time zone for clock elements in the temporal position

label: Observation Collection
definition: An Observation Collection has at least one member, and may have one of any of the other seven properties mentioned in restrictions.

label: Organization
definition: Represents a collection of people organized together into a community or other social, commercial or political structure. The group has some common purpose or reason for existence which goes beyond the set of people belonging to it and can act as an Agent. Organizations are often decomposed into hierarchical structures.

label: Organizational Unit
definition: An Organization such as a department or support unit which is part of some larger Organization and only has full recognition within the context of that Organization. In particular the unit would not be regarded as a legal entity in its own right.

label: Organizational Unit
definition: Usage: Units can be large and complex containing other Units.

label: Actuatable Property
definition: An actuatable quality (property, characteristic) of a FeatureOfInterest.

label: Actuation
definition: An Actuation carries out an (Actuation) Procedure to change the state of the world using an Actuator.

label: Actuator
definition: A device that is used by, or implements, an (Actuation) Procedure that changes the state of the world.

label: Feature Of Interest
definition: The thing whose property is being estimated or calculated in the course of an Observation to arrive at a Result or whose property is being manipulated by an Actuator, or which is being sampled or transformed in an act of Sampling.

label: Observable Property
definition: An observable quality (property, characteristic) of a FeatureOfInterest.

label: Observation
definition: Act of carrying out an (Observation) Procedure to estimate or calculate a value of a property of a FeatureOfInterest. Links to a Sensor to describe what made the Observation and how; links to an ObservableProperty to describe what the result is an estimate of, and to a FeatureOfInterest to detail what that property was associated with.

label: Platform
definition: A Platform is an entity that hosts other entities, particularly Sensors, Actuators, Samplers, and other Platforms.

label: Procedure
definition: A workflow, protocol, plan, algorithm, or computational method specifying how to make an Observation, create a Sample, or make a change to the state of the world (via an Actuator). A Procedure is re-usable, and might be involved in many Observations, Samplings, or Actuations. It explains the steps to be carried out to arrive at reproducible results.

label: Result
definition: The Result of an Observation, Actuation, or act of Sampling. To store an observation's simple result value one can use the hasSimpleResult property.

label: Sample
definition: A Sample is the result from an act of Sampling.

label: Sample
definition: Feature which is intended to be representative of a FeatureOfInterest on which Observations may be made.

label: Sample
definition: Physical samples are sometimes known as 'specimens'.

label: Sample
definition:
Samples are artifacts of an observational strategy, and have no significant function outside of their role in the observation process. The characteristics of the samples themselves are of little interest, except perhaps to the manager of a sampling campaign.

A Sample is intended to sample some FatureOfInterest, so there is an expectation of at least one isSampleOf property. However, in some cases the identity, and even the exact type, of the sampled feature may not be known when observations are made using the sampling features.

label: Sampler
definition: A device that is used by, or implements, a Sampling Procedure to create or transform one or more samples.

label: Sampling
definition: An act of Sampling carries out a sampling Procedure to create or transform one or more samples.

label: Sensor
definition: Device, agent (including humans), or software (simulation) involved in, or implementing, a Procedure. Sensors respond to a stimulus, e.g., a change in the environment, or input data composed from the results of prior Observations, and generate a Result. Sensors can be hosted by Platforms.

label: Relationship Nature
definition: Nature of a relationship (between samples) - Members of this class indicate the nature of a relationship between two samples.

label: Sample Relationship
definition: Members of this class represent a relationship between a sample and another.

label: Condition
definition: Used to specify ranges for qualities that act as Condition on a Systems' operation.

label: Deployment
definition: Describes the Deployment of one or more Systems for a particular purpose. Deployment may be done on a Platform.

label: Input
definition: Any information that is provided to a Procedure for its use.

label: Output
definition: Any information that is reported from a Procedure.

label: Oversampling Rate
definition: Specifies the number of sensor measurements used internally to generate one sensor output result. (Oversampling rate = OSR)

label: Property
definition: A quality of an entity. An aspect of an entity that is intrinsic to and cannot exist without the entity.

label: Stimulus
definition: An event in the real world that 'triggers' the Sensor. The properties associated to the Stimulus may be different to the eventual observed ObservableProperty. It is the event, not the object, that triggers the Sensor.

label: System
definition: System is a unit of abstraction for pieces of infrastructure that implement Procedures. A System may have components, its subsystems, which are other systems.

label: Accuracy
definition: The closeness of agreement between the Result of an Observation (resp. The command of an Actuation) and the true value of the observed ObservableProperty (resp. Of the acted on ActuableProperty) under the defined Conditions.

label: Actuation Range
definition: The range of property values that can be the Result of an Actuation under the defined Conditions.

label: Battery Lifetime
definition: Total useful life of a System's battery in the specified Conditions.

label: Detection Limit
definition: An observed value for which the probability of falsely claiming the absence of a component in a material is beta, given a probability alpha of falsely claiming its presence.

label: Drift
definition: As a Sensor Property: a continuous or incremental change in the reported values of Observations over time for an unchanging Property under the defined Conditions. As an Actuator Property: a continuous or incremental change in the true value of the acted on ActuableProperty over time for an unchanging command under the defined Conditions.

label: Frequency
definition: The smallest possible time between one Observation, Actuation, or Sampling and the next, under the defined Conditions.

label: Latency
definition: The time between a command for an Observation and the Sensor providing a Result, under the defined Conditions.

label: Maintenance Schdule
definition: Schedule of maintenance for a System in the specified Conditions.

label: Measurement Range
definition: The set of values that the Sensor can return as the Result of an Observation under the defined Conditions with the defined system properties.

label: Operating Power Range
definition: Power range in which System is expected to operate in the specified.

label: Operating Property
definition: An identifiable characteristic that represents how the System operates under the specified Conditions. May describe power ranges, power sources, standard configurations, attachments and the like.

label: Operating Range
definition:
"Describes normal OperatingProperties of a System under some specified Conditions. For example, to the power requirement or maintenance schedule of a System under a specified temperature range.
In the absence of OperatingProperties, it simply describes the Conditions in which a System is expected to operate."

label: Precision
definition: As a sensor capability: The closeness of agreement between replicate Observations on an unchanged or similar quality value: i.e., a measure of a Sensor's ability to consistently reproduce an Observation, under the defined Conditions.

label: Resolution
definition: As an actuator capability: The closeness of agreement between replicate Actuations for an unchanged or similar command: i.e., a measure of an Actuator's ability to consistently reproduce an Actuations, under the defined Conditions.

label: Response Time
definition: As a Sensor Property: the time between a (step) change in the value of an observed ObservableProperty and a Sensor (possibly with specified error) 'settling' on an observed value, under the defined Conditions.

label: Selectivity
definition: As an Actuator Property: the time between a (step) change in the command of an Actuator and the 'settling' of the value of the acted on ActuatableProperty, under the defined Conditions.

label: Sensitivity
definition: As a Sensor Property: Sensitivity is the quotient of the change in a Result of Observations and the corresponding change in a value of an ObservableProperty being observed, under the defined Conditions.

label: Survival Property
definition: An identifiable characteristic that represents the extent of the System's useful life under the specified Conditions. May describe for example total battery life or number of recharges, or, for Sensors that are used only a fixed number of times, the number of Observations that can be made before the sensing capability is depleted.

label: Survival Range
definition:
"Describes SurvivalProperties of a System under some specified Conditions. For example, the lifetime of a System under a specified temperature range.
In the absence of SurvivalProperties, simply describes the Conditions a System can be exposed to without damage. For example, the temperature range a System can withstand before being considered damaged."

label: System Capability
definition: Describes normal measurement, actuation, sampling properties such as accuracy, range, precision, etc. Of a System under some specified Conditions such as temperature range. The capabilities specified here are those that affect the primary purpose of the System, while those in OperatingRange represent the system's normal operating environment, including Conditions that don't affect the Observations or the Actuations.

label: System Lifetime
definition: The System continues to operate as defined using SystemCapability. If, however, the SurvivalRange is violated, the System is 'damaged' and SystemCapability specifications may no longer hold.

label: System Property
definition: An identifiable and observable characteristic that represents the system's ability to operate its primary purpose: a sensor to make Observations, an Actuator to make Actuations, or a Sampler to make Sampling.

label: Application
definition: A way in which something can be used for a particular purpose.

label: Cloud Lobe
definition:
Cloud refers to a network of remote servers that store, manage, and process data and applications, providing on-demand access and scalable computing resources over the internet.

The Cloud lobe of the Digital Reference ontology models AH Local Cloud, Communication Technology, Data Format and Model, Device, and Documentation Document.
It also maps the topics of Information Model, Local Network, Method, SoA Property, Software and Software System, system Documentation and System of Systems.
It represents the notion of  Service, Service Documentation, Service-Oriented Architecture and Architecture Protocols.

label: Cloud Lobe
definition: Lobe owner: Jerker Delsing

label: Geographical Location
definition: Name of country or region

label: Organization Lobe
definition: The Organization Lobe refers to the structural and managerial aspects such as organizational structure, roles and responsibilities, efficient coordination and collaboration among various stakeholders within the semiconductor supply chains.

label: Organization Lobe
definition: Lobe owner: Marta Bonik

label: Planning Lobe
definition: Lobe owner: Hans Ehm

label: Planning Lobe
definition: The Planning Lobe is about making strategic decisions and creating comprehensive plans to ensure the efficient and effective flow of materials, products, and information throughout the manufacturing and distribution process. In includes information about marketing and sales demans, demand march, aggregated capacity, capacity bottlenecks, orders and customers.

label: Power Lobe
definition:
Power refers to the electrical energy consumed or dissipated by electronic devices or components during their operation, and is a crucial consideration for efficiency and performance optimization.

The Power lobe models the Amplication Switching Device, Control Method, Device Configuration and Element, Document, Entity, and Gate Driver.
It also represents the notions of Industrial Sector, Information Object, Operation Mode, Process, Process Input and Output.
It maps the topics of Product, Resistance, SiC MOSFET, switcher, and Voltage.

label: Power Lobe
definition: Lobe owner: Hans Ehm

label: Process Lobe
definition:
Process refers to a series of interconnected and sequential actions, steps, or operations designed to achieve a specific outcome or goal within a system or organization.

The Process lobe of the Digital Reference ontology represents the topics of Agent, Business Process Flow, Function and Function Object.
It also maps the notions of Goal, Input, Model and Model Element, Output, Screen, and Value-added Chain Diagram.

label: Process Lobe
definition: Lobe owner: Hans Ehm

label: Product Lobe
definition:
A product is a tangible or intangible item or service that is created, manufactured, or offered to fulfill a need or desire of customers.

The Product Lobe maps the notions of Customer Part Number Specification, Design Target, Integration Level, Main Power Device Type, Motor Type and Organization.
It also models Packing Type, Planning Element, Price Indication, Product, Qualification, Semiconductor Product Status, Solution, and Topology.

label: Product Lobe
definition: Lobe owner: Marta Bonik

label: Public Holiday
definition: Special period of time when some processes may not take place or some constrains may occure

label: Semiconductor Development Lobe
definition:
Semiconductor development refers to the process of researching, designing, and creating semiconductor devices to meet technological advancements and industry demands.

The Semiconductor Development lobe of the Digital Reference models the Current Work In Progress, Cycle Time and Delivery Commitment, EPA, Equipment and Equipent Group, and Event Calendar.
It reprensents the notions of Mask, Material Transfer Matrix, Operation, Operator, Owner, Planning Work Center, Plant,  and Process.
It also maps the topics of Product Level, Target Revenue and Service Level, Technology, Time Constraints, Tool, and Workshop.

label: Semiconductor Development Lobe
definition: Lobe owner: Hans Ehm

label: Semiconductor Production Lobe
definition: Lobe owner: Philipp Ulrich

label: Semiconductor Production Lobe
definition:
Semiconductor production refers to the manufacturing process of creating integrated circuits and other semiconductor devices by deposing, patterning, and doping various materials on a substrate to form electronic components.

The Semiconductor Production lobe represents the notions of Bottleneck, Capacity, Demand Snapshot, Fabrication, Furnace Process, Lot, Lot Event and Size.
It also maps the topics of Physical Resource, Priority Class, Product, Production Request, Purge, Release Plan, and Robot.
It models Route, Shift, Simulation Part and Route, Supply Chain, Target Costs and Work In Progress Station.

label: Sensor Lobe
definition:
A sensor is a device or component that detects and measures physical, chemical or environmental parameters and converts them into electrical signals for futher analysis or use.

The Sensor lobes models the notion of a System and its Deployment.
It maps the topics of Actuation, Feature of Interest, Input, Mounting Style, Observation and Observation Collection, and  Output.
It also represents Platform, Procedure, Property, Relationship Nature, Result, Sample Relationship, Sampling, Sensing Type, and Stimulus.

label: Sensor Lobe
definition: Lobe owner: Marta Bonik

label: Supply Chain Lobe
definition:
Supply chain refers to a network of interconnected organizations, activities, resources, and technologies involved in the production, distribution, and delivery of goods or services from the source to end consumer.

The Supply Chain lobe models the Aggregated Capacity Group.

 It represents the notions of Action, Allocated Available To Promise, Allocation, Available To Promise, Confirmation, Capacity Bottleneck, Contact Person Data, Location, Marketing Demand, nEWs, Offer, Open Oder and Open Order Book.

It depicts the Order and its Change Request, Confirmation, Line Item, Reschedule, Schedule Line.

It represents the General Customers, the notion of Customer and its Data, Logistics Management Representative, Plant, Plant Data.
It also maps the topics of Prioritized Demand and Orders, Products, Promise, Sales Supplier, Seller, Supplier and its Data, Supply, Supply Demand Match and Picture, Target Allocation, Transfer Action, and User Action.

label: Supply Chain Lobe

label: Sustainability Lobe
definition:
Sustainability refers to the practice of meeting present needs without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs, balancing environmental, social, and economic considerations.

This lobes models Application.

label: Sustainability Lobe
definition: Lobe owner: Philipp Ulrich

label: System Lobe
definition:
A system is a collection of interconnected components or elements that work together to perform a specific function or achieve a particular objective.

This lobe of the Digital Reference models the I 4.0 Component, the Asset it represents, the Admin Shell and its differents Views, Standard and Standard Organization. It also represents the notions of Date, Dimension, Measures, Semantic Expresison and Version.

label: System Lobe
definition: Lobe owner: Marta Bonik

label: Time Lobe
definition:
Time refers to a measurable dimension in which events occur sequentially and can be used to qualify the duration between occurences.

This lobe of the digital reference represents the topics of Temporal Duration, Position and Reference Position, the Time Zone, Months and Days of the week.

label: Time Lobe
definition: Lobe owner: Philipp Ulrich

label: Wired Communication Lobe
definition:
Wired communication refers to the transmission of data or signals through physical connections such as cables or wires.

This lobe represents the units of technical data transfer, product lifecycle phase, standard unit and vocabulary. It models Fieldbus and its 7 OSI layers, ISA-95, IT system and vendor, the service-oriented architecture and the standardization organisation.

label: AH Application Service
definition: Application services – they are application specific and are implemented by application systems along with functionalities (to match requirements of an application)

Arrowhead Core Component
definition:
Software system, that belongs to the "standard" components offered by Arrowhead framework.
Arrowhead core systems can occur once in each Arrowhead Local Cloud.
Arriwhead Core Systems can be distinguished in Arrowhead Mandatory Core Systems and Automation supporting systems. Mandatory core systems must exist in each Arrowhead Local Cloud, Automation supporting systems can occur in an Arrowhead Local Cloud.

Software system, that belongs to the "standard" components offered by Arrowhead framework.
Arrowhead core systems can occur once in each Arrowhead Local Cloud.
Arriwhead Core Systems can be distinguished in Arrowhead Mandatory Core Systems and Automation supporting systems. Mandatory core systems must exist in each Arrowhead Local Cloud, Automation supporting systems can occur in an Arrowhead Local Cloud.

AH Mandatory Core Service IDD
definition:
Class of all Interface Design Descriptions (IDDs) of mandatory Arrowwhead core services.
While the class AH_mandatory_core_service contains the mandatory core services only as instances, this class contains classes of the IDDs of each single mandatory core service as subclasses (not only as instances). Since each AH Local Cloud runs one instance of each mandatory core service, each of these services has to be documented by an AH service documentation, i.e. at least by a SD and a IDD. So the IDD is an individual document for each mandatory core service in each single Local Cloud. Hence, all IDDs of a certain mandatory core service will be individuals of the corresponding IDD class.

label: AH Mandatory Core System Sy SD
AH Mandatory Core System Sy SDD
AH Service Documentation Document
definition:
Document belonging to the documentation of an Arrowhead Service.
There are four types of documents for Arrowhead service documentations:
- Service Description
- Interface Design Description
- Communication Profile
- Semantic Profile.
The central documents are IDDs. They document the implementation of a certain service based on a certain communication technology (communication, encoding, data format) and a certain information model.
The Service Description contains a more general description of the service, without the link to a specific communication technology or information model.
Communication Profiles and Semantic Profiles are optional documents for a service documentation. They can be seen as modules of an IDD, since they can describe the communication technolopgy and the information model of a service implementation as external documents. If they exist, the IDD refers to them instead of declaring these contents by themselfes.
That is, CP and SP are useful if different service implementations use the same CP and SP - then their IDDs can refer to one and the same CP or SP document.

Communication Profile
definition: Communication Profile (CP)

label: Communication Security Mechanism
definition: corresponds to a part of OSI layer 5

label: Communication Technology
definition: Communications technology, also known as information technology, refers to all equipment and programs that are used to process and communicate information.

label: Constrained Device
definition:
A constrained device is a device in the sense of an service-oriented architecture that is restricted in terms of processing capabilities (speed, complexity of operations), memory and power supply.
The concept constrained device was introduced in the context of the Internet of Things (IoT) and refers for example to sensor devices, location devices, switches etc. which are connected by low-power wireless communication technologies like BLE, ZigBee, Z-Wave etc., have a battery on board that should last for two to three years and which are (very) small in physical size.

label: Data Format
definition: Data format in information technology may refer to: Data type, constraint placed upon the interpretation of data in a type system.

label: Data Link Media Access Technology
definition: corresponds to OSI layer 1 and 2 technologies, like Ethernet, WLAN (802.11), WPAN (802.15.4), EtherCAT, ProfiNet, ...

label: Data Model
definition: A data model is an abstract model that organizes elements of data and standardizes how they relate to one another and to the properties of real-world entities.

label: Device
definition: A device in the context of Arrowhead framework is a piece of equipment, machine, hardware, etc. with computational, memory, and communication capabilities which hosts one or several Arrowhead Framework systems. (Source: Arrowhead)

label: Device
definition: A device in the context of Service-oriented architectures (that is, in the context of Information Technology (IT) and Automation / Operations Technology (OT)) is an technical artefact that fulfills the basic definition of a "computer". That is, a device must be able to host (run) software systems. For this, it needs at least a processing unit (processor), a memory and a communication interface, which can be either wired or wireless.

label: Documentation Document
definition: A document that documents something

label: End-to-End Communication Technology
definition: The end-to-end principle is a design framework in computer networking. In networks designed according to this principle, application-specific features reside in the communicating end nodes of the network, rather than in intermediary nodes, such as gateways and routers, that exist to establish the network.

label: Gateway
definition: A gateway is a piece of networking hardware used in telecommunications for telecommunications networks that allows data to flow from one discrete network to another.

label: Illumination Device
definition: A category of devices which's purpose is to illuminate

label: Industrial Personal Computer
definition: Industrial PCs are primarily used for process control and/or data acquisition. In some cases, an industrial PC is simply used as a front-end to another control computer in a distributed processing environment.

label: Information Model
definition: An information model in software engineering is a representation of concepts and the relationships, constraints, rules, and operations to specify data semantics for a chosen domain of discourse. Typically it specifies relations between kinds of things, but may also include relations with individual things.

label: Interface Design Description IDD
definition: Interface Design Description (IDD)

label: Local Network
definition: A local area network is a computer network that interconnects computers within a limited area

label: Method
definition: Method of a service: method that is provided by a service within a SoA.

label: Personal Computer
definition: A personal computer (PC) is a multi-purpose computer whose size, capabilities, and price make it feasible for individual use.

label: Point-to-Point Communication Technology
definition: corresponds to OSI layer 3, e.g. IPv4 or IPv6

label: Programmable Logic Controller
definition: A programmable logic controller (PLC) is an industrial digital computer which has been ruggedized and adapted for the control of manufacturing processes

label: SPS
definition: A programmable logic controller (PLC) is an industrial digital computer which has been ruggedized and adapted for the control of manufacturing processes

label: Raspberry Pi
definition: The Raspberry Pi is a series of small single-board computers developed in the United Kingdom by the Raspberry Pi Foundation to put the power of computing and digital making into the hands of people all over the world.

label: Semantic Profile
definition: Semantic Profile (SP)

label: Sensor Device
definition: A category of devices which's purpose is to sense

label: Service
definition:
In the context of the Arrowhead Framework a Service is the information exchanged from a providing system to a consuming system.
• is based on a number of service orientation principles derived from high level objectives and properties of the Arrowhead framework
• can be realized by an arbitrary number of service producers and service consumers
• a system can consume a number of services, process and provide other services to fulfil a more complex task
• can only be provided by technical systems
• can support operational activities within business processes
• can support non-functional requirements, such as real-time
• can have stakeholders, with an interest in business benefit, in one or more specific area of interest
• can have an appointed stakeholder, responsible for the governance of the Service (definition, development).
(Source: Arrowhead Framework Definitions V2.4 & Arrowhead Device Registry Presentation)

label: Service Description SD
definition: Service Description (SD)

label: Service Documentation
definition: Service documentation is any communicable material that is used to describe, explain or instruct regarding some attributes of a service

label: Service-Oriented Architecture
definition: Service-oriented architecture (SoA) is a style of software design where services are provided to the other components by application components, through a communication protocol over a network.

label: Smartphone
definition: A smartphone is a mobile device that combines cellular and mobile computing functions into one unit.

label: Software System
definition: System software is software designed to provide a platform for other software.

label: Switch Device
definition: A switch is a device in a computer network that connects other devices together.

label: System Documentation
definition: System documentation is any communicable material that is used to describe, explain or instruct regarding some attributes of a system

label: System Of Systems
definition: System of systems is a collection of task-oriented or dedicated systems that pool their resources and capabilities together to create a new, more complex system which offers more functionality and performance than simply the sum of the constituent systems.

label: System Of Systems Description So SD
System Of Systems Design Description So SDD
System Web Application Description WADL
definition:
Description of an Arrowhead compliant software system in terms of the Web Application Description Language WADL.
The Web Application Description Language (WADL) is a machine-readable XML description of HTTP-based web services. WADL models the resources provided by a service and the relationships between them. WADL is intended to simplify the reuse of web services that are based on the existing HTTP architecture of the Web. It is platform and language independent and aims to promote reuse of applications beyond the basic use in a web browser.
WADL is the REST equivalent of SOAP's Web Services Description Language (WSDL), which can also be used to describe REST web services. Sources: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_Application_Description_Language
Sun Microsystems (31 August 2009). "Web Application Description Language: W3C Member Submission 31 August 2009". World Wide Web Consortium. Retrieved 12 August 2012.
World Wide Web Consortium (14 October 2009). "Team Comment on the "Web Application Description Language" Submission". World Wide Web Consortium. Retrieved 12 August 2012.
Lawrence Mandel (29 May 2008). "Describe REST Web services with WSDL 2.0: A how-to guide". IBM. Retrieved 12 August 2012.

label: Tablet Computer
definition: A tablet computer, commonly shortened to tablet, is a mobile device, typically with a mobile operating system and touchscreen display

label: Transfer Protocol
definition: corresponds to OSI layers 6 and 7

label: ANSI
definition: Is a private non-profit organization that oversees the development of voluntary consensus standards for products, services, processes, systems, and personnel in the United States.

label: ANSI Standard
definition: American National Standards Institute is a private non-profit organization that oversees the development of voluntary consensus standards for products, services, processes, systems, and personnel in the United States.

label: ANSI X12 Data Format
definition: Is predominant in North America.

label: APS
definition: Advanced planning and scheduling system (APS) refers to a manufacturing management process by which raw materials and production capacity are optimally allocated to meet demand.

label: Auto Gration Specification
definition:
XML Schema describing the Grammar of data content representing the content of a set of EDIFACT messages.
Relies on XML as data syntax, XML Schema as knowledge representation scheme and on EDIFACT message specifications (like ORDER, ORDRSP, DELFOR, DELJIT etc.). Has no Semantics representation.

label: B2MML-Based Service
definition: B2MML consists of a set of XML schemas written using the World Wide Web Consortium's XML Schema language (XSD) that implement the data models in the ISA-95 standard.

label: BI System
definition: Business intelligence system (BI) comprises the strategies and technologies used by enterprises for the data analysis and management of business information.

label: CAD System
definition: Computer-aided design system (CAD) is used for creation, modification, analysis, or optimization of a design.

label: Character Set
definition: Is a collection of characters that might be used by multiple languages.

label: Comma Separated Values
definition: Comma Separated Values (CSV) is a delimited text file that uses a comma to separate values. Each line of the file is a data record.

label: Communication Device
definition: A communications device is any type of hardware capable of transmitting data, instructions, and information between a sending device and a receiving device.

label: Computer
definition: A computer is a machine that can be instructed to carry out sequences of arithmetic or logical operations automatically via computer programming.

label: Control Device
definition: Output devices that work in conjunction with sensor input devices and commands from computers in order to control a process.

label: Data Language Semantic Web Stack Based
Data Transmission Unit
definition: Units of technical data transfer. Shows the different data groupings at the  ISO/OSI communication layers, e.g. bits on the physical link layer and packets at the network layer.

label: Database System
definition: Is an organized collection of data, generally stored and accessed electronically from a computer system.

label: Digital Factory System
definition:
The term "Digital Factory" is used in different meanings today and should hence not longer be used.
It should be replaced by more specific terms like "Digital Factory Planning system" or "Digital Factory Twin".
Originally, Digital Factory referred to software tools for computer-aided planning, design, engineering and simulation of production, manufacturing, or assembly systems. These tools supplemented CAD-based tools for factory layout planning and tools for computer-aided tools for production engineering (work plan preparation, production process planning) and were glued together with them to PLM software suites.
As today even CAD-based layout planning and process planning tools are "digital" and refer to the factory, the terms "Digital Factory tool" and "Production Engineering tool" more and more converge.
At the same time, automation vendors start to use the concept "Digital Factory" to address online monitoring and control tools for production systems. In this meaning, the term is a synonym for "Digital Factory Twin" or "Digital Twin of a Factory".
The important difference between these two meanings is the phase in the life cycle in which the tool is used: Manufacturing Planning / Eingineering is conducted mainly in the first two lifecycle phases in which the product (type, class) is created, designed, and engineered, as well as the corresponding production system.
The online monitoring and control is conducted during the third phase, in which the product individuals are produced on the existing production system.
Hartwig Baumgaertel, 2018-11-12

label: Fieldbus Communication Profile Family
definition:
A field bus is a bus system that connects field devices such as sensors and actuators in a plant for the purpose of communication with an automation device. If several communication participants send their messages over the same line, then it must be specified who (identifier) says what (measured value, command) and when (initiative). There are standardized protocols for this.
The first generation of fieldbus technology was developed in the 1980s to replace the parallel wiring of binary signals and analog signal transmission that had been common until then with digital transmission technology. Today, many different fieldbus systems with different characteristics are established on the market. Since 1999, fieldbuses have been standardized worldwide in the IEC 61158 standard (Digital data communication for measurement and control - Fieldbus for use in industrial control systems) and by the IEC 61784 standard.
The second generation of fieldbus technology is based on real-time Ethernet (Industrial Ethernet).

A fieldbus defines a complete protocol stack over the 7 layers of the OSI layer model. If necessary, not all layers are occupied.

Example for first generation fieldbus is Profibus,
Example for second generation fieldbus is ProfiNet.

label: Fieldbus Communication Profile Family
definition:
Ein Feldbus ist ein Bussystem, das in einer Anlage Feldgeräte wie Messfühler (Sensoren) und Stellglieder (Aktoren) zwecks Kommunikation mit einem Automatisierungsgerät verbindet. Wenn mehrere Kommunikationsteilnehmer ihre Nachrichten über dieselbe Leitung senden, dann muss festgelegt sein, wer (Kennung) was (Messwert, Befehl) wann (Initiative) sagt. Hierfür gibt es normierte Protokolle.
Die erste Generation der Feldbustechnik wurde in den 1980er Jahren entwickelt, um die bis dahin übliche Parallelverdrahtung binärer Signale sowie die analoge Signalübertragung durch digitale Übertragungstechnik zu ersetzen. Heute sind viele unterschiedliche Feldbussysteme mit unterschiedlichen Eigenschaften am Markt etabliert. Seit 1999 werden Feldbusse in der Norm IEC 61158 (Digital data communication for measurement and control - Fieldbus for use in industrial control systems) sowie durch die Norm IEC 61784 weltweit standardisiert.
Die zweite Generation der Feldbustechnik basiert auf Echtzeit-Ethernet (Industrial Ethernet).

label: MQTT
definition:
MQTT[1] (Message Queuing Telemetry Transport) is an ISO standard (ISO/IEC PRF 20922)[2] publish-subscribe-based messaging protocol. It works on top of the TCP/IP protocol. It is designed for connections with remote locations where a "small code footprint" is required or the network bandwidth is limited. The publish-subscribe messaging pattern requires a message broker.

Andy Stanford-Clark of IBM and Arlen Nipper of Cirrus Link authored the first version of the protocol in 1999.[3]

The specification does not specify the meaning of "small code footprint" or the meaning of "limited network bandwidth". Thus, the protocol's availability for use depends on the context. In 2013, IBM submitted MQTT v3.1 to the OASIS specification body with a charter that ensured only minor changes to the specification could be accepted.[4] MQTT-SN[5] is a variation of the main protocol aimed at embedded devices on non-TCP/IP networks, such as ZigBee.

Historically, the "MQ" in "MQTT" came from IBM's MQ Series message queuing product line.[6] However, queuing itself is not required to be supported as a standard feature in all situations.[7]

Alternative protocols include the Advanced Message Queuing Protocol (AMQP), Streaming Text Oriented Messaging Protocol (STOMP), the IETF Constrained Application Protocol,[8] XMPP,[9][10] DDS,[11] OPC UA,[12] and Web Application Messaging Protocol (WAMP). (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MQTT)

label: SCTP
definition: Das Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP) ist ein zuverlässiges, verbindungsorientiertes Netzwerkprotokoll. Es gehört zur Transportschicht und setzt auf einem potenziell unzuverlässigen, verbindungslosen Paketdienst auf.

label: SCTP
definition:
Es wurde von der Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) als neues Transportprotokoll vorgeschlagen und im Oktober 2000 in dem Standarddokument RFC 2960 veröffentlicht und im September 2007 durch RFC 4960 erweitert. Eine Einführung findet sich auch in RFC 3286. Das zuständige Gremium bei der IETF ist die Arbeitsgruppe Signaling Transport, kurz SIGTRAN.

Als Transportprotokoll steht SCTP auf derselben Stufe des TCP/IP-Referenzmodells wie TCP und UDP (Schicht 4 des OSI-Modells).

SCTP realisiert das Konzept einer Association: Hier wird eine Verbindung aufgebaut, in der mehrere Nachrichten-Datenströme in sich reihenfolgenerhaltend (untereinander aber potentiell nicht-reihenfolgenerhaltend) transportiert werden. Zusätzlich können einzelne, zum Beispiel dringende, Datagramme separat und außer der Reihe verschickt werden, die dadurch eventuell die In-Order-Datenströme „überholen“.

SCTP kennt außerdem Multistreaming und Multihoming (ein Host mit mehreren gültigen IP-Adressen). Es werden Heartbeats verwendet, um aktiv auf Verbindungsabriss zu testen.

Anders als TCP zeigt sich SCTP resistent gegen SYN-Flooding, eine Denial-of-Service-Attacke, bei der durch halboffene Verbindungen die Ressourcen des Servers aufgebraucht werden. Dazu verwendet es einen sogenannten Vier-Wege-Handshake. Hierbei speichert der Server bei einer Verbindungsanfrage (INIT-Paket) keine Zustandsinformationen, sondern schickt diese in Form eines Cookies (INIT-ACK-Paket) an den Client. Der Client muss dieses Cookie in seine Antwort (COOKIE-ECHO-Paket) einfügen und wird damit vom Server als zum Verbindungsaufbau berechtigt erkannt, was dieser ihm bestätigt (COOKIE-ACK-Paket). Ein ähnliches Verfahren ist mit TCP ebenfalls möglich, siehe SYN-Cookies.

Ursprünglich wurde SCTP als Transportprotokoll definiert, um Zeichengabenachrichten (SS7) aus Telefonnetzen auch über IP-Netzwerke übertragen zu können. Bei der Entwicklung stand insbesondere die Zuverlässigkeit des Protokolls im Vordergrund. SCTP ist aber auch für andere Anwendungen geeignet, da es Vorteile von TCP und UDP vereint. Eine wichtige, auf SCTP aufbauende Anwendung ist Reliable Server Pooling (RSerPool).

SCTP verwendet für Fluss- und Überlastkontrolle ähnliche Algorithmen wie TCP, verhält sich also in einem gemischten Netz (SCTP und TCP) neutral.[1]

Auch Java bietet seit Version 7 eine eigene API für SCTP an.

label: SCTP
definition:
It was proposed by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) as a new transport protocol and published in October 2000 in the standard document RFC 2960 and extended in September 2007 by RFC 4960. An introduction can also be found in RFC 3286. The responsible body at the IETF is the Signaling Transport Working Group, or SIGTRAN for short.

As a transport protocol, SCTP is on the same level of the TCP/IP reference model as TCP and UDP (layer 4 of the OSI model).

SCTP implements the concept of an association: A connection is set up in which several message data streams are transported in a sequence-preserving manner (but potentially non-sequence-preserving among themselves). In addition, individual datagrams, for example urgent datagrams, can be sent separately and out of sequence, possibly "overtaking" the in-order data streams.

SCTP also knows multistreaming and multihoming (one host with several valid IP addresses). Heartbeats are used to actively test for connection failure.

Unlike TCP, SCTP is resistant to SYN flooding, a denial-of-service attack in which half-open connections use up the server's resources. It uses a so-called four-way handshake for this purpose. Here, the server does not store any state information in a connection request (INIT packet), but sends it to the client in the form of a cookie (INIT-ACK packet). The client must include this cookie in its response (COOKIE-ECHO packet) and is thus recognized by the server as authorized to establish a connection, which the server confirms to it (COOKIE-ACK packet). A similar procedure is also possible with TCP, see SYN cookies.

SCTP was originally defined as a transport protocol for transmitting signalling messages (SS7) from telephone networks over IP networks. During development, the reliability of the protocol was a particular focus. However, SCTP is also suitable for other applications because it combines the advantages of TCP and UDP. An important application based on SCTP is Reliable Server Pooling (RSerPool).

SCTP uses similar algorithms as TCP for flow and congestion control, so it behaves neutrally in a mixed network (SCTP and TCP)[1].

Java also provides its own API for SCTP since version 7.

label: Transportation
definition: The various modes or means of transportation.

label: Type Of The Transportation
definition: The type or category of transportation, such as road, air, rail, or water.

label: Wind Turbine
definition: A device that converts wind energy into electricity.

label: Activity
definition: Additional lobes: Time

label: Activity
definition: An activity is something carried out over a specific time interval.

label: Allocated Available To Promise
definition: ALLOCATED AVAILABLE TO PROMISE is when scarce ATP quantities are allocated to different customer classes or customers. The resulting supply reservations are called allocated ATP (AATP) quantities.

label: Allocation Plan
definition: An allocation plan is a special plan, which deals with assigning ATP quantities to a customer or a customer class.

label: Available To Promise
definition: AVAILABLE TO PROMISE is the part of the inventory and projected supply that can be used to fulfill customer orders is called ATP.

label: Batch Interval
definition: This is the time span for which arriving orders are collected to derive for all of them jointly a first promised delivery date.

label: Best Promised Delivery Date
definition: This is the best delivery date the supplier ever promised to the customer. It represents the best delivery date the supplier submitted to the customer. Thus every later commitment or delivery is a de-commitment from the supplier.

label: Complete Delivery
definition: The normal case is that an order is completely delivered.

label: Confirmed Delivery Date
definition: The CDD is the committed date for order delivery that is communicated to the costumer. It depends on the communication strategy between manufacturer and customer. For instance, the CDD is the PDD if order repromising takes place in the same frequency as the update interval of the CDD.

label: Customer
definition:
CUSTOMER is a person, organization, or business entity that generates demand by placing an order or making a request for a specific product or service. A customer may also fulfill their obligations by facilitating payment for the goods or services received.

Customers can be categorized into two main types: 
•	External Customers: Entities outside the organization that purchase goods or services, often governed by agreements like Incoterms.
•	Internal Customers: Stakeholders or departments within the organization that raise internal demand for products or services to support internal processes.

A customer interacts with the organization through actions such as order placement, demand generation, and the completion of financial transactions. Customers are central to both demand creation in the supply chain and the fulfillment processes that ensure the delivery of goods or services.

label: Customer Class
definition: CUSTOMER CLASS is the set of all customers is divided into different priority classes or segments based on certain criteria like profitability or importance of customer.

label: Customer Order
definition: This is an order that is initiated by a customer.

label: Date
definition: Additional lobe: Supply Chain

label: Date
definition: The availability date defines the point in time when the supply is available to the customer. It can be distinguished between different availability dates. Not all availability dates are communicated to the customer.

label: Delivery Concept
definition: The DELIVERY CONCEPT defines the terms and conditions for delivering an order to the customer. Partial and split delivery has to be taken into account.

label: Delivery Date
definition: This is the point in time when the customer received the requested order.

label: Demand
definition: DEMAND is a supply chain or production request for a specific product, product group or service. Either demand exists explicitly in form of customer need (e.g. orders or EDI forecast) or implicitly as expected customer need.

label: Demand Class
definition: The DEMAND CLASS is dividing the demand into priority classes.

label: Demand Priority
definition: DEMAND PRIORITY is the concept that is used to describe the different importance level of a demand. The demand priority can be assigned independently from the demand class.

label: Engineering Lot
definition: An engineering lot requires additional process development efforts and special attention during the production flow. Engineering lots have various functions, thus several engineering lot types can be differentiated.

label: Firm Order Demand
definition: This is a special demand class that is used for demand that is required to fulfill already committed/accepted orders.

label: First Promised Delivery Date
definition: Initially, the FPD is set for an order delivery within the online order confirmation process.

label: Forecasted Demand
definition: This is a special demand class that is used for the projection of future demand.

label: Inventory Replenishment Demand
definition: This is a special demand class that is used for replenishment of safety stock.

label: Last Promised Delivery Date
definition: This is the last commitment the supplier has given to the customer

label: Location
definition:
LOCATION refers to a physical or virtual place where an action, process, or activity occurs, playing a critical role in the execution of tasks within the supply chain, production, and planning systems.

•	Logistics perspective: A location signifies the point where responsibility, ownership, or risk transitions between parties during the transfer of goods or services.
•	Demand Fulfillment Perspective: A location represents the origin or destination of demand-related processes, such as the point of product dispatch, delivery to customers, or storage of inventory to meet customer needs.
•	Planning Perspective: Locations are key inputs for planning activities, representing the physical sites or nodes in the supply chain (e.g., factories, warehouses, or distribution centers) where resources, capacity, or inventory must be allocated.
•	Semiconductor Production Perspective: In manufacturing, a location indicates a specific site where production steps take place, such as fabrication, assembly, or testing.

LOCATIONS are fundamental to managing supply chain efficiency, tracking material flow, coordinating production processes, and ensuring timely fulfillment of customer orders.

label: Lot
definition: A lot is a set of wafers, substrates or modules that travel together through the FE or BE fab in order to fulfill a certain order.

label: Master Plan
definition: A master plan is a specific plan which determines which quantity resulting from confirmed orders and from forecasted demand should be completed in which location in which period of the planning horizon. Moreover, outsourcing decisions have to be represented in master plans.

label: Order
definition: An ORDER contains at least one order position. An ORDER has an order type and is associated to DEMAND.

label: Order Delivery Plan
definition: This is the result of the order promise or repromise process for different sets of orders taking into account an allocation policy and the supply and allocation situation. Different order promising variants can be distinguished, for instance online order promising, batch order promising, and hybrid order promising. The same is true of repromising.

label: Order Position
definition: An ORDER POSITION refers to a product specification, a product quantity, and a desired delivery date. Each order position has a status and belongs to an order.

label: Order Promising
definition: This concept describes the process to promise an order considering allocation policy as well as supply and allocation situation. The order promising can be distinguished between different variants, for instance online order promising and batch order promising.

label: Partial Delivery
definition: It can be allowed that only parts of an order position of an order are delivered. Therefore, the customer is willing to waive parts of quantity belonging to an order position.

label: Period
definition: The concept period displays the sub unit of the planning horizon.

label: Plan
definition: A PLAN is an activity specification with an intended purpose.

label: Planning
definition: PLANNING is an activity with the purpose to determine a plan. Planning is associated with goals, represented by objective functions to be optimized.

label: Planning Period
definition: A planning period is a specific DateTimeInterval from the time ontology (Time Ontology 2020). It belongs to a planning window. It has a temporal duration.

label: Planning Purpose
definition: The PLANNING PURPOSE specifies the objectives of a certain planning activity. It is given by a set of performance measures that are related to a set of PLANNING OBJECTS.

label: Planning Window
definition: Planning in supply chains is associated with a planning window which is formed by a set of consecutive planning periods.

label: Product
definition: A PRODUCT is a good that fulfills a prescribed set of requirements (for instance, form, fit, and function). A set of alternative BOMs might be associated with each product. The manufacturing process is complicated by binning and substitution (in production). Binning refers to the process that an item can become one of several products based on tested levels of performance, for instance, speed.

label: Product Aggregate
definition: The concept product aggregate is used to group different products based on certain criteria. The grouping criteria depend on the planning purpose (e.g. controlling, production). It is a certain view (external or internal) on a set of products.

label: Product Hierarchy
definition: The concept characterizes the top-down and bottom-up relationship between different product aggregates. It organizes the product aggregates according to defined criteria.

label: Production Strategy
definition: The PRODUCTION STRATEGY determining which portions of a supply chain should operate in make to stock (MTS) mode, where production is driven by the replenishment of inventories at specific locations, and which in make to order (MTO) mode, where production is initiated to fulfill specific customer orders. The production strategy is related to the question where the customer order decoupling point (CODP), also referred to as the push-pull interface (or boundary) has to be placed. The CODP denotes the point in the supply chain where material is dedicated to a specific customer order to the degree that it cannot be used for another.

label: Productive Lot
definition: A productive lot is created to fulfill a customer demand. The production process is carried out as it is defined during the production development phase.

label: Promised Delivery Date
definition: This is the date for which eventually partial order delivery is confirmed. The PDD date can be changed over time. Within the repromising process there are typically different PDDs available.

label: Replenishment Order
definition: This is an order that is initiated by an internal request of the semiconductor manufacturer to produce the order according to a MTS strategy. The replenishment order can be divided into different sub order types, depending on the purpose of order creation.

label: Requested Delivery Date
definition: The RDD is the point in time when the customer wants to get the order.

label: Route
definition: Additional lobes: Semiconductor Production

label: Route
definition: The term route can be considered on different levels. In the present situation, a route is associated with a product and describes its production flow on the production network level.

label: Split Delivery
definition: It can be allowed that order positions of an order are delivered in several portions.

label: Split Order
definition: This is an order that results from a split delivery. When an order position of an order is delivered in several portions, each portion starting from the second one is considered as a separate suborder which is called scheduled order position. The original order also exists after the split.

label: Supplier
definition: A SUPPLIER is an entity fulfilling a demand for a specific product or service.

label: Supply
definition: SUPPLY is the total amount of specific products or services that is available to customers. Supply has the dimensions quantity, time, location, product, including aggregation of all dimensions. Supply is defined as inventory or plan replenishment.

label: Supply Chain
definition: A SUPPLY CHAIN is the network of organizations, resources, activities, and technologies involved in the production and delivery of a product from raw materials to the final customer. Supply chain management issues have become increasingly important to the semiconductor industry due to the global distribution of facilities and its inherent long production time.

label: Supply Contract
definition: A SUPPLY CONTRACT is a formal agreement between two parties—typically a supplier and a buyer—that outlines the terms and conditions under which goods or services will be provided over a specified period. The contract establishes a legally binding relationship and is commonly used in business-to-business transactions.

label: Time Interval
definition: Additional lobe: Planning

label: Assemble To Order
definition: In the case of ATO, products are produced forecast-driven until the point right before it comes to the assembly. Starting from there, the production continues based on a customer order.

label: Bill Of Material (BOM)
definition: A BOM describes components or rather semi-finished products that are part of the finished product. Substitution, often associated with binning, is based on the possibility that alternative items might be used to finish a process step. This leads to the notion of alternative BOMs.

label: Make To Order
definition: This is a strategy where production is initiated to fulfill specific customer orders. This strategy is characterized by an order-driven production.

label: Make To Stock
definition: This is a strategy where production is driven by the replenishment of inventories at specific locations. Products are produced forecast-driven until they are completely finished in the case of MTS.

label: Capability
definition: Ratio of the theoretical available recipes at a tool and the available recipes

label: Delivery Commitment
definition: DELIVERY COMMITMENT refers to the agreed-upon date or timeframe by which a product, service, or solution is promised to be delivered to a customer. It is a key component of supply chain, project management, and customer service operations, ensuring alignment between supplier capabilities and customer expectations.

label: Demand Snapshot
definition: A DEMAND SNAPSHOT is a fixed capture of demand data at a given point in time. It allows comparison over time or alignment between supply and demand planning cycles.

label: Demand Trace
definition: DEMAND TRACE is the tracking of demand from final customer requests through the supply chain, enabling visibility of demand origins.

label: Equipment
definition: Equipment name. Machine of one equipment type that can execute certain production (or measurement) steps

label: Equipment Group
definition: Equipment Group Name. Group of same type of machines for production of certain production steps

label: Fab
definition: The name of the fab producing the product. Production Area

label: Location
definition:
LOCATION refers to a physical or virtual place where an action, process, or activity occurs, playing a critical role in the execution of tasks within the supply chain, production, and planning systems.

•	Logistics perspective: A location signifies the point where responsibility, ownership, or risk transitions between parties during the transfer of goods or services.
•	Demand Fulfillment Perspective: A location represents the origin or destination of demand-related processes, such as the point of product dispatch, delivery to customers, or storage of inventory to meet customer needs.
•	Planning Perspective: Locations are key inputs for planning activities, representing the physical sites or nodes in the supply chain (e.g., factories, warehouses, or distribution centers) where resources, capacity, or inventory must be allocated.
•	Semiconductor Production Perspective: In manufacturing, a location indicates a specific site where production steps take place, such as fabrication, assembly, or testing.

LOCATIONS are fundamental to managing supply chain efficiency, tracking material flow, coordinating production processes, and ensuring timely fulfillment of customer orders.

label: Lot_Event
definition: Gives the history of lot events (Processing, Hold, Split, Merge, etc.) and equivalently to the lots, the equipment also has to be historically tracked

label: Lot_State
definition: Covers all historical processes start and end of a lot in any facility and provides the full history of operations of a specific lot

label: Maintenance
definition: Includes all different maintenance types and their durations and it can be described several times and can vary slightly between the equipment

label: Plant
definition: Production location with decentral planning and control unit

label: Product Level 2
definition: Product Name

label: Recipe
definition: Recipe required at a specific step. The production pattern of a specific production step on equipment

label: Release_Plan
definition: Quantity planned to be released to a plant or facility

label: Route
definition: Route name. Define the route that produces a product. Order of production steps for one product

label: Setup
definition: Tool status for preparing for the next lot

label: Supply Chain
definition: A SUPPLY CHAIN is the network of organizations, resources, activities, and technologies involved in the production and delivery of a product from raw materials to the final customer. Supply chain management issues have become increasingly important to the semiconductor industry due to the global distribution of facilities and its inherent long production time.

label: Workshop
definition: Additional lobe: Semiconductor Development

label: C_Main_Carriage_Paid
definition: An Incoterms rule of the group C.

label: D_Arrival
definition: An Incoterms rule of the group D.

label: E_Departure
definition: An Incoterms rule of the group E.

label: Exchange Rate Specification
definition: EXCHANGE RATE SPECIFICATION is structured value representing exchange rate.

label: F_Main_Carriage_Unpaid
definition: An Incoterms rule of the group F.

label: From_Location
definition: A sub property of location. The original location of the object or the agent before the action.

label: Incoterms_2020
definition:
The Incoterms or International Commercial Terms are a series of pre-defined commercial terms published by the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) relating to international commercial law. They are widely used in international commercial transactions or procurement processes and their use is encouraged by trade councils, courts and international lawyers.

Incoterms 2020 is the ninth set of international contract terms published by the International Chamber of Commerce, with the first set having been published in 1936. Incoterms 2020 defines 11 rules, the same number as defined by Incoterms 2010.

label: Incoterms_Application_Mode
definition: Incoterms_Application_Mode is about the method of delivery the incoterm uses. An incoterm could use only ship or non-ship transport.

label: Incoterms_Clause
definition: An Incoterms_Clause is a term of the 11 pre-defined incoterms.

label: Incoterms_Group
definition: An Incoterms_Group is one of the four categories that describes incoterms rules.

label: Location
definition:
LOCATION refers to a physical or virtual place where an action, process, or activity occurs, playing a critical role in the execution of tasks within the supply chain, production, and planning systems.

•	Logistics perspective: A location signifies the point where responsibility, ownership, or risk transitions between parties during the transfer of goods or services.
•	Demand Fulfillment Perspective: A location represents the origin or destination of demand-related processes, such as the point of product dispatch, delivery to customers, or storage of inventory to meet customer needs.
•	Planning Perspective: Locations are key inputs for planning activities, representing the physical sites or nodes in the supply chain (e.g., factories, warehouses, or distribution centers) where resources, capacity, or inventory must be allocated.
•	Semiconductor Production Perspective: In manufacturing, a location indicates a specific site where production steps take place, such as fabrication, assembly, or testing.

LOCATIONS are fundamental to managing supply chain efficiency, tracking material flow, coordinating production processes, and ensuring timely fulfillment of customer orders.

label: Offer
definition: An OFFER is a proposal to provide goods, like products or services in exchange for something of value, such as money.

label: Only_Ship_Transport_Clause
definition: Incoterms that solely involve transportation by water.

label: Product
definition:
PRODUCT is any tangible or intangible output that fulfills a prescribed set of requirements and is intended for delivery to a customer or end user. A product may result from mechanical, industrial, or other manufacturing processes and is created to meet specific customer needs, such as form, function, or performance.

Products can be classified as: 
•	Tangible Products: Physical goods, such as semiconductor chips, electronic devices, or finished consumer electronics.
•	Intangible Products: Services or deliverables that do not have a physical form but provide value, such as software, maintenance services, or intellectual property.

Products often involve complexities across their lifecycle, including manufacturing, transfer, and categorization. In manufacturing, they may use alternative Bills of Materials (BOMs) and processes like binning, categorizing variations based on performance (e.g., speed or functionality), with substitutions addressing supply chain constraints. Commercially, products serve as objects of transfer, shifting ownership or responsibility per agreements like Incoterms. They can also be represented as individual tangible instances (e.g., a smartphone), prototypes defining specifications, or placeholders for mass-produced commodities with unspecified details.

label: Seller
definition: SELLER is an entity which offers the services/goods.

label: To_Location
definition: A sub property of location. The final location of the object or the agent after the action.

label: Transfer Action
definition: TRANSFER ACTION is the act of transferring/moving objects from one place to another.

label: Universal_Transport_Clause
definition: Incoterms that may be used regardless of the method of transport.

label: Action
definition: ACTION is the process of doing something.

label: Allocation
definition: ALLOCATION is a process used in supply chain (e.g. order management) in times when demand exceeds available supply.

label: Contact Person Data
definition: CONTACT PERSON DATA refers to the detailed information (name, role, email, phone) of a person responsible for handling specific transactions or communications in the supply chain process.

label: Customer
definition:
CUSTOMER is a person, organization, or business entity that generates demand by placing an order or making a request for a specific product or service. A customer may also fulfill their obligations by facilitating payment for the goods or services received.

Customers can be categorized into two main types: 
•	External Customers: Entities outside the organization that purchase goods or services, often governed by agreements like Incoterms.
•	Internal Customers: Stakeholders or departments within the organization that raise internal demand for products or services to support internal processes.

A customer interacts with the organization through actions such as order placement, demand generation, and the completion of financial transactions. Customers are central to both demand creation in the supply chain and the fulfillment processes that ensure the delivery of goods or services.

label: Customer Data
definition: CUSTOMER DATA includes all information necessary to manage orders—such as identifiers, addresses, logistics preferences, and contractual conditions.

label: Customer Plant
definition: A CUSTOMER PLANT refers to the physical location or facility owned or operated by a customer where products, systems, or services are delivered, installed, maintained, or utilized.

label: Customer Plant Data
definition: CUSTOMER PLANT DATA refers to the structured and unstructured information associated with a customer's plant.

label: Demand Fulfillement
definition: DEMAND FULFILLEMENT is the process of meeting a customer´s demand for product or services by fulfilling their request.

label: Demand Fulfillement
definition: DEMAND FULFILLEMENT refers to the set of processes by which a company responds to customer demand by delivering products or services. In the semiconductor supply chain, it includes order promising, product allocation, scheduling, and ensuring timely delivery. It represents the interface between the supply chain and external customers, ensuring that demand is met in accordance with business rules and available resources. It represents the interface between the supply chain and its external customers.” It also connects closely with Available to Promise (ATP) mechanisms that decide what can be committed to customers based on current and projected inventory and capacity.

label: Open Order
definition: OPEN ORDER refers to a customer order that has been received and recorded in the system but has not yet been fully processed, shipped, or fulfilled. It represents a pending obligation within the sales or supply chain process.

label: Open Order Book
definition: OPEN ORDER BOOK refers to a real-time record of all active, unfulfilled customer orders within an organization. It includes detailed information on sales orders.

label: Order Change Request
definition: An ORDER CHANGE REQUEST is a formal request initiated by a customer or internal stakeholder to modify an existing order after it has been placed but before it is fully fulfilled or invoiced. This request can include changes to product quantities, item specifications, delivery dates, shipping addresses, or other order-related details.

label: Order Confirmation
definition: ORDER CONFIRMATION is a formal acknowledgment from the seller to the customer that an order has been received, reviewed, and accepted under the specified terms and conditions.

label: Order Line Item
definition: An ORDER LINE ITEM is an individual entry within a customer order that specifies the details of a specific product or service being purchased. Each line item represents a unique combination of product, quantity, and pricing, and collectively, line items make up the full contents of an order. A new order line item might be generated when partial fulfillment is committed or delivered.

label: Supplier
definition: A SUPPLIER is an entity fulfilling a demand for a specific product or service.

label: Supplier Data
definition: Information about a supplier.

label: Supply
definition: SUPPLY is the total amount of specific products or services that is available to customers. Supply has the dimensions quantity, time, location, product, including aggregation of all dimensions. Supply is defined as inventory or plan replenishment.

label: User Action
definition: USER ACTION refers to any interaction a user makes with a system, application, or interface—such as clicking a button, submitting a form, or navigating a page—that triggers a response or function.

label: Additional Power Management
definition: A semiconductor product which is used within the context of additional power management

label: Angle Sensor
definition: Infineon offers a family of angle sensors based on integrated Magneto Resistive (ixMR) technologies. Technologies include today iGMR and AMR. The sensors detect the orientation of an applied magnetic field by measuring sine and cosine angle components with monolithically integrated magneto resistive elements. ixMR technology is now widely used in automotive and industrial applications and provides a wide range of benefits. Our iAMR sensors are ideal for applications with the highest accuracy requirements. Our iAMR technology offers best performance over temperature, lifetime and magnetic field range. They are pre-calibrated and ready to use.

label: Application Area
definition: A way in which something can be used for a particular purpose.

label: Application Level 1
definition: The top application level which can have several sub application levels (application level 2)

label: Application Level 2
definition: The medium application level which can have several sub application levels (application level 3) and can be assigned to super application levels (application level 1)

label: Application Level 3
definition: The lowest application level which can be assigned to super application levels (application level 2)

label: Business_Line
definition: A business line is an organizational unit that can be assigned to a division and can have one or more product lines.

label: Completely Lead Free Status
definition: This status determines whether a semiconductor product is lead free or not.

label: Design Target
definition: Semiconductor solutions are design for different purposes, with different design goals respectively. Design targets comprise "flexible to design", "easy to design" and "allrounder".

label: Digital Barometric Pressure Sensor
definition: Infineon’s  DPS310 is a miniaturized digital barometric pressure sensor which offers high accuracy and low current consumption, and is capable of measuring both pressure and temperature. A sealed capacitive sensing element is used for pressure measurement, guaranteeing high precision and accuracy across temperature changes. The small package and low energy consumption make  DPS310 ideal for mobile applications and wearable devices.

label: Discrete Power Stage
definition: A semiconductor product which is used within a discrete power stage

label: Division
definition: A division is a administrative business unit that is smaller than the whole company, but it is self-contained and most often responsible for its own revenue, cost, and profit. It has one or more business lines.

label: Gate Driver
definition: A semiconductor product which is used as a gate driver

label: Hall Switch
definition: The sensor provides an easy-to-use and cost effective solution for position sensing applications, requiring high temperature stability of the magnetic threshold. Today the market demands smaller and more energy efficient Hall switches. To satisfy the needs of more compact designs and environmental legislation  with a high quality product is very difficult. Infineon offers attractive pricing, reliable supply, benchmark quality and excellent design-in support to contribute to the customers success.

label: Halogen Free Status
definition: This status determines whether a semiconductor product is halogen free or not.

label: Industry
definition: An application area on top level (corresponing to application level 1) which can have several sub application levels (main application)

label: Integrated Pressure Sensor
definition: Infineon offers a different range of barometric air pressure sensor for automotive and industrial applications. The barometric air pressure (BAP) is an important parameter to compute the air-fuel ratio provided to the engine and for controlling spark advance to optimize engine efficiency. In automotive applications where high production volumes are common there is substantial interest in precision, low-cost and fully integrated sensors.

label: Integration Level
definition: Each motor control and drive solution has an integration level which states if the different stage are built in an integrated or discrete way. The stages of a motor control and drive solution are "Controller", "Driver", "Power Stage". Following this, the different integration levels are "discrete" (not integrated), "fully integrated", "integrated controller driver", "integrated driver power stage", "integrated power stage".

label: Intelligent Power Module
definition: A semiconductor product which is used as intelligent power module

label: Linear Hall Sensor
definition:
Measure the vertical component of a magnetic field and outputs a signal that is directly proportional to the magnetic field. These programmable linear Hall sensors come with different interface options.
